componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Raytheon Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Michael, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Marc Kaplan, Vice President of Investor Relations. You may proceed, sir.

headline: Raytheon Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today on our fourth quarter conference call. The results that we announced this morning, the audio feed of this call and the slides that we'll reference are available on our website
componenttext: Thank you, Michael. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today on our fourth quarter conference call. The results that we announced this morning, the audio feed of this call and the slides that we'll reference are available on our website at raytheon.com. Following the live call, an archive of both the audio replay and a printable version of the slides will be available in the Investor Relations section of our website. With me today are Bill Swanson, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Dave Wajsgras, our Chief Financial Officer. We'll start with the brief remarks by Bill and Dave, then we'll on to questions. Please limit your questions to one per caller to allow for broader participation.Before I turn the call over to Bill, I'd like to caution you regarding our forward-looking statements. Any matters discussed today that are not historical facts, particularly comments regarding the company's future plans, objectives and expected performance constitute forward-looking statements. These statements are based on a wide range of assumptions that the company believes are reasonable but are subject to a range of uncertainties and risks that are summarized at the end of our earnings release, and that we discussed in detail in our SEC filings. Bill?

headline: Raytheon Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone. 2009 was another good year for the company, and we remain confident about our future. Clearly, there were significant and very challenges to many business around the world this past year. Yet within this environmen
componenttext: Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone. 2009 was another good year for the company, and we remain confident about our future. Clearly, there were significant and very challenges to many business around the world this past year. Yet within this environment, we stayed true to the strategic direction we set several years ago. We have the right strategy, the right processes and the right talent in place to meet our customers' needs and to deliver strong financial results. We believe our performance reflects the strength of our strategic planning and execution, and our company's alignment with customer priorities. We're well positioned to take advantage of the changes taking place in the world, to build on our record of performance and to create value for our customers and our shareholders.Looking at 2009, we had a book-to-bill ratio of greater than one, and we ended the year with a backlog of $37 billion, including the highest year-end funded backlog in the company's history. Our full year sales were up 7%. Our EPS was up 24%. We generated strong cash flow, and we continued to improve our return on invested capital. As we mentioned in October, we expect to deliver solid growth in 2010. Dave will provide you with more color on our financial performance, both for the quarter and for the year in a few minutes and our outlook for 2010. But I wanted to first hit a couple of the highlights. We continue to see good performance across our portfolio, which is recognized by our customers. It's clearly a major contributing factor to our growth, both in the U.S. and international markets.Within these markets, we're seeing strong demand in important areas to Raytheon. A good example is missile defense. The administration has identified our Standard Missile-3 and X-band radars as critical elements in the missile defense systems for the U.S. and our allies around the world. Other countries like the UAE, Taiwan and Japan that confirmed their need for world-class capabilities. We're seeing strong support domestically and international for our intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance work, particularly in the classified arena. There's also increasing demand for our Homeland Security Solutions, which were highlighted by a $446 million international classified award in the fourth quarter. Our bookings in Homeland Security doubled in 2009, and our sales growth over the past two years have averaged just under 20%.Training also continues to be a strong area. We booked $1.3 billion in domestic and foreign operational training programs during 2009. As you would expect, there's also increasing demand for our world-class cyber solutions, which are setting new standards in the emerging market space. And our core business continued to do well. In Missiles, for example, we're seeing strong demand for AMRAAM  [Advanced Medium-Range Air-to-Air Missile], Evolved SeaSparrow, Standard Missile-2, TOW [Tube-launched, Optically-tracked, Wire-guided] and Phalanx, just to mention a few. In addition to focusing our customers to meet their priorities, as a technology company, we are able to both forward fit and backward fit our solutions to enhance our customers' capabilities. As a result, we are able to react quickly to meet our customers mission-critical needs at an affordable cost. Our broad range of customer span, the major U.S. defense and security agencies, and we do business in 80 countries around the world. 30% of our total bookings and 21% of our total sales during the year were from international customers. Going forward, we believe that our international business will continue to be a key driver in Raytheon's growth.In summary, our businesses are performing well with over 8,000 programs and 15,000 contracts. We have a diverse portfolio. We are well positioned, and we will continue to be a predictable performer. Our portfolio is built on capabilities that support and meet the global needs of our customers both today and tomorrow. With that, I'd like to recognize the entire Raytheon team for successfully executing our strategy and supporting our customer-focused mission, which is to ensure customer success.We started in 2009 with 73,000 employees, and we begin the new year with 75,000 strong. All of us are committed to our customers and our shareholders, and we're excited about the future. With that, I'll now turn it over to Dave.

headline: Raytheon Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. I have a few opening remarks starting with the fourth quarter and full year results. And I'll discuss our outlook for 2010 and after that, Bill and I will open up the call for questions. During my remarks, I
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. I have a few opening remarks starting with the fourth quarter and full year results. And I'll discuss our outlook for 2010 and after that, Bill and I will open up the call for questions. During my remarks, I'll be referring to the web slides that we issued earlier this morning, which are posted on our website. Okay. So if everyone would please move to Page 3, we delivered strong results in both the quarter and the full year. We booked $25.1 billion in new business, ending the year with a $36.9 billion backlog. Our 10% sales growth during the quarter and 7% sales growth for the year highlight the continued demand for our solutions and the strength of our business. Fourth quarter EPS from continuing operations was $1.30, up 29% and for the full year, $4.89, up 24%. We also generated strong operating cash flow of $2.7 billion during the year. For 2010, we expect another year of solid sales growth and strong operational performance, and we're reaffirming the guidance that we've provided you on October. I'll discuss our guidance further in just a few minutes.If you'd now turn to Page 4, I'll go through some the details of our fourth quarter and full year results. Again strong bookings of $7.1 billion in the quarter and $25.1 billion for the full year resulted in a backlog of $36.9 billion. 39% of our total bookings during the quarter and 30% of our total bookings for the year were from international customers. As a reminder, in Q4 of 2008, we had especially strong bookings primarily related to the $2.5 billion UAE Patriot contract. Our book-to-bill ratio for both the fourth quarter and the full year of 2009 was greater than one, which bodes well for our future. Here are some of the highlights during the quarter. IDS booked $990 million to provide advanced Patriot Air and Missile Defense capability for Taiwan, and $160 million related to the renewal of an international Patriot technical support contract. IDS also booked $315 million for systems design work for the Zumwalt-class destroyer for the U.S. Navy. IIS booked $153 million on a contract to provide ISR support to the U.S. Air Force, and $519 million on a number of classified contracts.Missile Systems booked $222 million for the production of SM-2 for international customers in the U.S. Navy, and a little over $100 million for the development of SM-3 for the Missile Defense Agency. MS also booked $201 million for the production of the Evolved SeaSparrow Missile for international customers in the U.S. Navy, $170 million for the production of Maverick missiles for an international customer and $111 million for the production of TOW missiles for international customers and the U.S. Army.NCS booked $446 million on an international classified program. NCS also booked an additional $127 million for a TOW system replacement program. SAS booked $122 million for the B-2 Radar program, and $131 million on a number of classified contracts. Technical Services booked $67 million for work on domestic operational training programs for the U.S. Army. If you'd move to Page 5, we continue to deliver strong sales growth, 10% on the quarter and 7% on the full year. IDS had fourth quarter 2009 net sales of $1.5 billion, up 8% for the quarter and 7% for the full year, primarily due to growth on international Patriot programs. IIS had fourth quarter 2009 net sales of $803 million. For the year, IIS net sales were up 2%, primarily the result of growth on various classified programs, partially offset as expected by lower sales on the international e-Borders program. As we said in the past, the initial development phase of this program was completed in the early part of 2009.Missile Systems net sales of $1.4 billion, up 3% for both the quarter and for the year. Missile's net sales in 2009 were driven by higher volume on the SM-3 and Maverick programs. NCS had fourth quarter 2009 net sales of $1.3 billion. For the quarter, sales were up 12% and for the year, sales were up 7%, primarily due to higher volume on various production programs mainly for the U.S. Army.Space and Airborne Systems had net sales of $1.3 billion in the quarter, up 9% and for the year, net sales of $4.6 billion, or up 7% driven by growth on their classified business. Technical Services had fourth quarter 2009 net sales of $888 million, up 19%, full year sales of $3.2 billion, or up 22%. The sales growth of TS during both periods was due to strong growth in domestic and foreign operational training programs supporting the U.S. Army, as well as on ATCOTS [Air Traffic Control Optimum Training Solution] program for the Federal Aviation Administration. Moving to Page 6, we delivered strong operational performance in both the quarter and the full year. Our total operating margin was up 130 basis points for the quarter and up 90 basis points for the year. As a reminder, our fourth quarter and full year 2008 operating margin included a $45 million after tax unfavorable CAS pension adjustment. This was due to the impact of pension asset returns on existing contracts during 2008.Looking at the business margins, IDS had solid results in both the quarter and the year. The change from 2008 was primarily driven by the change in contract mix that we discussed on prior calls. At IIS Missiles and TS, margins for the year remained consistent or slightly improved compared with 2008. NCS margin in the quarter was in line with the same period in 2008, and up 130 basis points for the year, primarily due to improved performance on a broad range of programs. And finally, SAS margin in the quarter was down about 60 basis points, primarily due to the timing of performance improvements in 2008 versus 2009. On a full year basis, SAS margin was up 80 basis points, primarily due to favorable mix as well as contractual settlements.Turning now to Page 7. Fourth quarter EPS from continuing operations was $1.30 versus $1.01 in 2008 The 29% increase was driven by operational improvements, reduced share count. The 2008 lower CAS pension adjustment, and lower FAS/CAS pension expense. We've also provided you with a summary of our one earnings per share result, excluding the impact of the FAS/CAS pension adjustment. We recognize that many analysts and investors look at FAS/CAS adjusted EPS as another important financial measure because it adjusts for the non-cash and temporary differences between FAS and CAS pension accounting. Fourth quarter 2009 FAS/CAS adjusted EPS was up 22%. We provided a reconciliation of this non-GAAP measure on Page 16 in the Appendix. Turning now to Page 8, our full year EPS from continuing operations was $4 and $0.89 versus $3.93 in 2008, an increase of 24% primarily due to operational improvements and reduced share count. Full year 2009 FAS/CAS adjusted EPS was up 18%. Before moving to our 2010 outlook, let me briefly comment on cash flow and summarize 2009. The company generated strong operating cash flow of $2.7 billion in 2009, compared to $2 billion in 2008. Improved performance, and on a net basis, lower cash tax payments were the primary drivers.Summarizing 2009, it was another very strong year for the company. As we've already mentioned, our book-to-bill ratio exceeded one. This is especially notable in light of our strong 7% sales growth. We continued to deliver solid margins and earnings per share. We generated $2.7 billion of operating cash flow. We repurchased $1.2 billion of stock, and we acquired BBN Technologies, a world leader in research and development and provider of critical solutions for national defense and security missions. Our track record of delivering strong operational and financial performance, and our solid balance sheet give us confidence as we focus on the future and flexibility as we continue to grow the business.Turning now to Page 9, we are reaffirming the financial outlook for 2010 that we provided in October. We expect continued growth in sales in the range of between $25.9 billion and $26.4 billion. As for pension, we now see FAS/CAS pension expense of $220 million versus the $228 million that we projected in October. The change is primarily driven by our asset returns in 2009, which were up over 17% for the full year. Our end-of-year discount rate was 6.25% consistent with what we had assumed in October. Next, we expect net interest expense to be between $95 million and $110 million, a slight change from our prior guidance but in-line with 2009. We see average diluted shares outstanding to be between $377 million and $382 million on a full year basis. As for effective tax rate, we want to be clear that for planning purposes and consistent with our prior practice, we're assuming that the R&D credit extension gets passed in 2010 retroactive for the full year. And accordingly, we've included it in our 2010 guidance. It favorably impacts the effective tax rate by 90 basis points and is worth about $0.07 in EPS. I'd also like to remind everyone that effective January 1, 2009, we were required to adopt the new accounting standard for non-controlling interests. For Raytheon, this relates primarily to Talus Raytheon Systems Company LLC, which is included in NCS financial results. EPS and EPS from continuing operations are calculated based on net income attributable to Raytheon Company, and income from continuing operations attributable to Raytheon Company, both of which we report separately on our income statement.In 2010, we expect EPS to be in the range of $4.75 to $4.90. We see our FAS/CAS adjusted EPS to be in the range of $5.13 to $5.28. You'll notice a slight change from our prior guidance on the FAS/CAS adjusted EPS line, and this is merely due to a change in the tax rate used in calculating the FAS/CAS impact. We believe using the statutory tax rate more precisely represents the tax impact of the  adjustment. Our operating cash flow guidance is unchanged from our prior guidance at $2 billion to $2.2 billion. A key driver of the difference in cash flow from 2009 is higher cash tax payments in 2010. And finally, we expect our return on invested capital to be between 12.2% and 12.6%. You should also be aware that we have updated our definition of our ROIC, which is included on Page 15, to now exclude the FAS/CAS pension adjustment. It better reflects how we measure the company's financial and operational performance.Continuing on to Page 10, I'll briefly comment on our outlook by business. First, we expect all of our businesses to grow and perform well in 2010. On a FAS/CAS adjusted basis, we expect to deliver solid margins by focusing on sales growth and operational performance across the company. If you'd move to Page 11, we've provided you with our 2010 outlook by quarter. You should note that in first quarter, we're impacted by both workdays and the timing of sales between Q4 2009 and Q1 of this year. Finally, on Page 12, we've provided you with a summary of the financial impact of pensions in 2009, as well as our assumptions for 2010. In 2010, we expect to make total cash contributions of approximately $1.1 billion, in line with what we contributed in 2009. So let me conclude by saying that we delivered strong results in 2009. We have a strong balance sheet, a diverse portfolio of innovative technologies, strong demand for our solutions, both domestically and internationally and we're confident in our ability to continue to deliver profitable growth in 2010. With that, Bill and I will open up the call to questions.

componenttext: Let me take them in kind of reverse order. On Seapower, clearly, we see the Navy sorting out their ship building program as they go through that. That's the challenge, and that will be coming out in the budget here in the next week or two. And for us, we clearly see the Navy trying to take a bigger interest in what I'll call missile defense. So we see a role there where at least [ph] our electronics and the gear we build will have a major impact on how the Navy does that mission. At the same time, I believe we're going to have to keep some ships floating longer than people anticipated, and so some backfit of our electronics there to keep this platform state-of-the-art. We'll probably play into that. And clearly, I know it would be me speculating, but I think the Navy is going to look at more network-centric capabilities of how they provide more data and sensor capability into the shooter, as I would call it. So that's kind of how I see the Navy going forward. As far as our businesses...

headline: Raytheon Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010

componenttext: Bill, before you jump into that, just a quick question. If CGX were to go away, is there any impact at this point or does it change anything from the long point of view?

headline: Raytheon Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, no, I don't think so. I think from our standpoint, we kind of look at it simply, in our terms, you always have to see something, so you need a radar. And we believe our dual-band radars of X and S band are kind of premier in the world. And so for us,
componenttext: No, no, I don't think so. I think from our standpoint, we kind of look at it simply, in our terms, you always have to see something, so you need a radar. And we believe our dual-band radars of X and S band are kind of premier in the world. And so for us, if it's going to float, you need to see something on it. You'll also need sonar systems to make sure underwater you know what's going on. And there again, that's in our wheelhouse. You've always got to have a missile on a ship, whatever ship it is and that's part of our strength. And then you need EW or close-in weapon support capability, and that's another area for us. So that's why I'm always so positive about our portfolio that if you think about it in mission terms, that's what we've got portfolios for to be able to adapt and change whichever way our customers are going. And then we've developed I think some speed of execution here that allows us to be flexible to meet those needs. So kind of I don't lose any sleep over that. There is always activity in the press on that, but we come out at a different way, if that helps.

componenttextpreview: Okay, Ron, that's a fair question since the last -- the person right before you asked the same question. So let me try to put just a little bit of color on that. First of all, all of our businesses are growing, and margins are up in each of our businesses
componenttext: Okay, Ron, that's a fair question since the last -- the person right before you asked the same question. So let me try to put just a little bit of color on that. First of all, all of our businesses are growing, and margins are up in each of our businesses from an operational perspective. You'll recall that SAS had claims in 2009, which amounted to about 40 basis points of improvement. So again on an operational basis, we're seeing improvement year-over-year. And the NCS is impacted by BBN and the related acquisition costs. If you stand back from all of this, growth of 4% to 6% is driven by both domestic and international sales. As for IDS, the implied growth of 3% to 7% driven by international Patriot programs. And that business benefits from production efficiencies as the volume ramps up in these programs. IIS, we see growth there coming primarily in the classified area. And we see performance improvement basically across the board in that business. You'll recall that that's where the main focus of our cyber efforts are managed. For Missile Systems, we're seeing strength in Phalanx and AMRAAM as we look to '10 and just general program efficiencies across the board. NCS, I've already addressed the impact of BBN, but they also, as Bill mentioned earlier, won an important classified program, an international classified program in the fourth quarter, that will be ramping up as well. From Technical Services standpoint, they have performed exceedingly well from a sales standpoint driven by the domestic and international training programs. We see growth on our war fighter focus efforts from roughly $1 billion in '09 to about $1.2 billion in '10, and again just general program efficiencies across the board in that business. SAS, I spoke a little bit about SAS. Their increase is driven primarily by volume on classified business, which we spoke to, and some continuing growth in international airborne tactical radars. Overall, performance is strong operationally. We've talked about SAS throughout the year, so we're confident in that business being able to deliver. I hope that gives you some color as to what we're seeing.

componenttext: Yes, I can, Howard. From a standpoint of what happened in our classified business, our customers in that arena face tough budget pressure. They've gone through and revamped a number of their programs. We had, let me say a few at least, that should've been awarded mid-year, couple [ph] came out near the end of the year and we have some this year. In fact, on major classified competitive award got awarded last night. I can't tell you that amount or who it is but clearly it was one we were counting on that last year. So that affected the number. If you look, overall at our classified bookings, they were about 18% of the total last quarter. For '09, our classified bookings in total were up 14% of our total bookings. That was up a little bit over '08. Our classified sales for last year were about 13% for growth rate of about 15% over 2008. And we expect classified sales to be about 14% roughly of our total this year and a growth rate of 10% to 15%. So in engineering terms, I'd call it an RC time constant that kind of got delayed a little bit, and not that things didn't happen, they got pushed a little bit to the right, and we expect the IIS to be okay this year, if that helps.

componenttext: Clearly, patriots getting a lot of attention. We expect -- we're sitting down, talking to Saudi Arabia. For them, they need to resert [ph] their missiles and they need to go through an upgrade to pack three. Taiwan actually had their first order placed last year. They need additional fire units, so we expect a few more for them. Israel will be having, and I should put in timetable that Saudi would like to see something this year, but that depends on the timing of our customers. Taiwan would probably be in late this year or '11 timeframe. Israel upgrading their fire units there and that's a little bit in '10, some in '11 and '12. Kuwait, we expect them to upgrade and get additional, that's probably early '11 unless something makes it go to left. Turkey, there's a potential for that late this year. They're going through their competitive assessment. And then Gutter [ph] looks like early '11 kind of timeframe. So for us, a lot of activity, there's other countries, but that's kind of where the focus of our effort is there. Plus ongoing tech-support, engineering services and logistics on patriot worldwide. Japan is also going through their analysis, we'll see their budget coming out of here shortly, and I expect more activity in Japan.

headline: Raytheon Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd probably say from a point of view, if you take our businesses in the missile world, we've got a great portfolio. I mean I think our missile operations are a national asset and they're world class in what they do. If you look at our SAS business,
componenttext: Yes, I'd probably say from a point of view, if you take our businesses in the missile world, we've got a great portfolio. I mean I think our missile operations are a national asset and they're world class in what they do. If you look at our SAS business, clearly, airborne radars are always a competitive world. And for us, with our RACR radar and we're trying to get into other markets, on platforms that we haven't been on. So there's competition there. The ISR world has been great growth for us. We have some of the best centers in the world that are built out at SAS. There's competition but we welcome it from a standpoint of given how we compete. Command-and-control is always a competitive field. There's a lot of players there, that will be in our NCS business. But internationally, we continue to do very well there. As we go about the intelligence and information business, when Howard's question, when you look at that, that's a competitive world, they have tight budgets. So we see competition in that business. In the missile defense arena and radars, clearly having radars that are affordable, that can see things that no one else can see, differentiate us. So our standpoint, we work hard on our technology to make sure we've got something that's better than what someone else is doing at an affordable price and the ability to turn it around quickly. Technical Services, the training and support business is always competitive. People are there, margins are in the 7% range, kind of plus and minus, and so you see that. But we feel pretty good about what we're doing, we have some innovative training. We've learned from our commercial side of the business. We do a lot of the automotive training for each of the automotive companies, and they made us figure out how to due compression in training. So we think it makes us competitive there.

headline: Raytheon Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The President said last night he's going to continue to grow defense while freezing most of the parts of the other federal budget, reaffirmed his commitment to Afghanistan, and it would seem to bode well. On the other hand, it might bring more scrutiny si
componenttext: The President said last night he's going to continue to grow defense while freezing most of the parts of the other federal budget, reaffirmed his commitment to Afghanistan, and it would seem to bode well. On the other hand, it might bring more scrutiny since the DoD, and only a few others have continued to get more money. And I wondered if you thought that there was some risk that the government might increase scrutiny, there's some big programs with some visible disappointments, I'm sure relative to what both the contractor and the government hoped. Whether you're seeing any rumblings of changes in the business relationship, it seem that Bob [ph] and Bill and Ashton Carter and Shay [ph], said some things need to change, I know you saw them all at AIA. Is there anything that you're seeing or that Raytheon's seeing that's sort of affecting the way the business is going? And is there anything you can do to protect against what they might do to sort of insulate yourself?

headline: Raytheon Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the way you protect yourself is you do better than what they expect on the contract. From our standpoint, performance is always been something that we try to drive into our DNA culture here in the company and part of it is, is that, how do we do bett
componenttext: Yes, the way you protect yourself is you do better than what they expect on the contract. From our standpoint, performance is always been something that we try to drive into our DNA culture here in the company and part of it is, is that, how do we do better than what we signed up for? How does our performance exceeded expectations? And I think Raytheon's margins are a reflection of our performance. That customers, and you've heard DoD talk about this, they're willing to pay for performance. But if you're not performing, they're not going to pay for it. And I've always had this saying, with things swim funny, the sharks come out and eat it. You don't want programs swimming funny. So we work very hard here to make sure our programs are green or blue and performing well. And I would applaud DoD, they've opened up communication, they talked about the issues that bother them, but there's an obligation to us as a contractor to perform. And I think that's how companies can and should insulate themselves. And scrutiny, you always have. These are taxpayer dollars and we're supposed to do our job, so that's kind of how I look at it in simple terms.

headline: Raytheon Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you see some stepping up? I can't tell whether this is talk or whether there really is change in the works. And I think you're right, I mean if you do great, you'll be fine.
componenttext: Do you see some stepping up? I can't tell whether this is talk or whether there really is change in the works. And I think you're right, I mean if you do great, you'll be fine.

headline: Raytheon Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and they've said it. If you're programs running right, then you ought to expect some bad things to happen to it. And I believe there's action taking place. The scrutiny is starting to take place. From a standpoint, the government has an obligation an
componenttext: Yes, and they've said it. If you're programs running right, then you ought to expect some bad things to happen to it. And I believe there's action taking place. The scrutiny is starting to take place. From a standpoint, the government has an obligation and it will put added pressure. It's normal in Washington that eight people aren't getting money and two people are. The two that are, are going to get a lot of visibility because the other eight are going to be complaining, that's just human nature. But you can, rest assured, from our standpoint that we're not wavering in the way we do business. And we're a company that does the open kimono here, that we want to make sure that we're transparent, not only to our customers, but to investors and shareholders.

componenttext: Bill, you went through, I guess with George earlier about some of the international patriot awards and it sounded like a lot of them are, some late '10 maybe even into '11, can you just talk more generally about the company in terms of what you assume, you'll see in order this year domestically versus internationally? componenttextpreview: Yes, as you know, the bookings are always lumpy. But to help you guys, I'll give you another number of about $26 billion, plus or minus $500 million, kind of in the range. We feel good about that. Our international business, from a standpoint, just to add
componenttext: Yes, as you know, the bookings are always lumpy. But to help you guys, I'll give you another number of about $26 billion, plus or minus $500 million, kind of in the range. We feel good about that. Our international business, from a standpoint, just to add a little more color, they were 39% of our bookings in the fourth quarter. Sales were about 23% in the fourth quarter. For the year, our bookings were about 30% of the total versus 28% in '08. International sales were about 21% of the total in '09, with a growth rate of about 15% over '08. So that was pretty good. International bookings, we expect to be in the 28% to 30% range for 2010. And if I remember right, sales for 2010 ought to be in a 22% to 24% range. So that's kind of how the mix goes if we look at 2010 in classified. We expect those to be 12%, plus or minus a little, and we expect our sales next year to be about 14% of total sales for a growth rate of about 10% to 15%. So, pretty much same kind of year this year. International doing what we said it would do a couple of years ago when we kind of took a look five years out, kind of see growth going and us going to a 25%, 75% mix. But I don't get hung up on the mix, what I get hung up on is having double-digit growth rate on of the volume as sales, because that's what really drives the business. So we got a couple of strategic pursuits this year to competitive. We've got GPS OCX and IIS. We've got a small diameter bomb where as you know, we came into that one late in the game, and we're trying to put a good effort for it to see what we can do on that. So that's kind of the color of the year that I see, and need to do, what we've been doing, and try and shorten the timelines because both domestically and internationally the awards are taking a little bit longer. And so our job is to do everything we can and try to move them to the left.

componenttext: We've talked about '10. With respect to '11, I did suggest on the last call that if the harmonization rules came out, I'd be able to add some more clarity. But let me just give you the short version. We had returns that approached 17.5% on our pension assets in 2009, so that did favorably impact '11 from what we were thinking just a few months ago. Cutting through all that, we sort of see the FAS/CAS pension adjustment in '11. And this is important, holding all the variables constant, discount rate, assumed long rate of return and other actuarial assumptions. If you hold all of those constant, it would approach about $300 million, so it could be up around $80 million. And we were thinking a little bit more than that just a few months ago. I want to repeat that doesn't include the potential favorable impact of cash harmonization. If that were to happen, it would move in the other direction, maybe to the benefit of $100 million, plus or minus. As we go to '12, it actually approaches break even. It's somewhere in the neighborhood of about a negative $50 million. And then as you go to 2013, you actually turn positive in the FAS/CAS adjusted basis.

componenttext: Clearly, we have a very strong balance sheet. We're exiting 2009 in a net cash position. Specifically, we have more cash on hand than we do debt. We talked about the pension funding being on gross level of about $1.1 billion. We'll continue, which is implied in the guidance, at some level with the repurchase plan, that we'll obviously be looking at the dividend program. And as Bill just mentioned, we're looking more closely at strategically important acquisitions. As Bill mentioned earlier, we're thinking in terms of maybe upwards to $500 million, plus or minus. These are more longer-term strategic investments that fit, from a technological standpoint into the portfolio, and help us grow longer term.

componenttext: That includes what we know about the budget process in Afghanistan, that's included in it. Regarding patriot, I don't have, off the top of my head, how many systems that we've got. I'd have to go through every country from memory that we've got, about 11, 12 countries that got patriot. Smallest number could be three fire units to one that up in the 20s. So that's kind of the range. But you can think of patriot as, there's always a sustaining effort. We're always doing engineering because there's obsolescence and parts that go out that you got to have a redesign effort to replenish. If you look at the UAE, there's a good redesign effort going on there with color displays, new comm, new antenna mass groups and so forth. Once we finish that development, then those will be offered to other countries. So patriot is one of the most unique systems in the world in the sense that it went through development, deployment, sustainment, and now it's starting all over again. Which means everybody that's got patriot always looks to upgrade it. So it's one of those nice hallmark systems, if that helps.

componenttext: I'll start with your last comment. I think we're very well positioned. I've talked earlier in my remarks that when you look up where the buildings going, clearly, they need to be able to handle both types of contingencies. And the one that demands more ISR, persistent ISR, is I think bigger operative word, how do you have a 24x7. Or as my wife says, 25x8 in our household. And so from that standpoint, that's where we excel. How do you net that information and provide it to others? if you look at our DCGS System 10.2, I call it Google with a clearance, you can pass data amongst your sensors and systems to anyone at various classified levels. If you look at Missile Defense, clearly, what we're trying to do at that arena with proven systems, SM-3 is the best in the world there and has one of the best test records. And our radars, as I mentioned, our X-band ground-based radars, there's nothing like them in the world, and why we feel comfortable with that. So that's getting some attention. I think the QDR will address cyber. We've live with .mil, .gov, .com. I think there may be a fourth domain here that people got to start thinking about. And we'll see what happens. But I suspect that's going to get some attention. So you look at all of that, that's what we've talking about the last few years of where we wanted to be. And I think, given our broad-based portfolio, it's helped us anticipate the future. So we look to it with optimism, not concern.

componenttext:
Thanks, Michael. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today on our first quarter conference call. The results that we announce this morning, the audio feed of this call and the slides that we'll reference are available on our website at www.raytheon.com. Following the live call, an archive of both the audio replay and a printable version of the slides will be available in the Investor Relations section of our website. 
With me today are Bill Swanson, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Dave Wajsgras, our Chief Financial Officer. We'll start with some brief remarks by Bill and Dave, and then we'll move on to questions. Please limit your questions to one per caller to allow for broader participation.
Before I turn the call over to Bill, I'd like to caution you regarding our forward-looking statements. Any matters discussed today that are not historical facts, particularly comments regarding the company's future plans, objectives and expected performance, constitute forward-looking statements. These statements are based on a wide range of assumptions that the company believes are reasonable, but are subject to a range of uncertainties and risks that are summarized at the end of our earnings release and that we discuss in detail in our SEC filings. Bill?

headline: Raytheon Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marc. Good morning, everyone. We had a strong quarter, and we're off to a good start for the year. The company had bookings of $6.5 billion and sales of $6.1 billion, a book-to-bill greater than 1. Our operating profit margins were solid, drive
componenttext:
Thank you, Marc. Good morning, everyone. We had a strong quarter, and we're off to a good start for the year. The company had bookings of $6.5 billion and sales of $6.1 billion, a book-to-bill greater than 1. Our operating profit margins were solid, driven by strong program performance. Our FAS/CAS adjusted EPS was up 17%, and we delivered good cash flow. Clearly, another solid quarter performance for the company.
As we mentioned in January, we expect to deliver continued growth for the year. Our results in the first quarter and our positive outlook are a result of our successful execution of our customer-focused strategy. There are a lot of exciting things going on in the company, so I wanted to do something a little bit different this morning and take a few minutes on this call to highlight some of them for you.
Let me start with IIS. We booked over $1.7 billion in new business, ending the quarter with a book-to-bill ratio close to 2.5x. IIS booked $886 million on a competitively awarded contract for the U.S. Air Force to develop the next generation ground control stations for GPS. We call the program GPS-OCX. The program will provide anti-jam capabilities for our war fighters, ensure future air traffic control systems and facilitate the advancement of commercial GPS applications. I'm very proud of our innovative solution, and the team is off to a great start.
IIS also booked $624 million on a number of classified contracts during the quarter, including $340 million on a major classified program. As many of you are aware, we can't say much about these programs, but it is clear that customers value the unique capabilities that we offer. The order book at IIS is very solid, and the business is well-positioned for future growth.
At our Integrated Defense Systems business, we delivered good growth and strong margins. Importantly, during the quarter, the Navy awarded initial funding for the third Zumwalt ship, a meaningful step toward addressing any questions about the outlook for this successful program. It's performing well and the advanced Technologies that we're developing will support the U.S. Navy and other navies for decades to come.
At Missile Systems, we've booked $535 million on a major classified program in the quarter. We also had a number of significant bookings for the Missile Defense Agency, the U.S. Navy, the U.S. Army and international customers. Missile Systems continues to be well-positioned for future growth. 
At Raytheon, we differentiate ourselves in the market based on our technologies and our focus on continuous innovation. I want to take a few minutes on the recent key technology wins across the company.
There's a lot of exciting work that we're doing to support our customers, which will drive future growth. For example, during the quarter we won a contract with the Office of Naval Research to continue our cutting-edge work on the compound semiconductor materials on silicon, or the COSMOS program as we call it. The potential future value of this disruptive technology that we're developing is significant, both to our customers and to Raytheon. We'll be able to deliver even more affordable sensors while continue to deliver world-class performance.
In the cyber area, we won a contract to provide critical experimentation and tests for the government cybersecurity capabilities. This win is a good example of our domain knowledge and our strengthening competitive position in this growing area. We were also awarded the final phase of a DARPA [Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency] contract called agile to develop speech and language processing technologies to recognize, analyze and translate speech and text into readable English and real-time on-the-fly. 
On the international side, our sales were up 20% during the quarter, and the percentage of our total sales from international continue to expand. It reached 23% in Q1. For the full year, we're forecasting double-digit growth in our international sales. We expect roughly 22% to 24% of our total sales in 2010 will come from international. There is strong, broad-based international demand for each of our businesses’ innovative solutions and technologies. For example, during the quarter, SAS booked $90 million for the production at Advanced Countermeasures Electronic Systems for the Egyptian Air Force's F-16s. It's another example of our focus on increasing both the breadth and total value of Raytheon technologies on the worldwide fleet of F-16s. 
In summary, we feel good about our accomplishments. Our strategy of focusing on the customer and exceeding expectations is working. In today's competitive landscape, we believe that our focus on performance relationships and solutions will continue to translate into even more opportunities in the future. 
With that, I'll now turn it over to Dave.

headline: Raytheon Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. I have a few opening remarks, starting with the first quarter highlights, and then we'll move on to questions. During my remarks, I'll be referring to the web slides that we issued earlier this morning.If everyo
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. I have a few opening remarks, starting with the first quarter highlights, and then we'll move on to questions. During my remarks, I'll be referring to the web slides that we issued earlier this morning.
If everyone could please move to Page 3. As Bill noted, we performed well in the first quarter. We had strong bookings of $6.5 billion and sales of $6.1 billion. And we ended the quarter with a $37 billion backlog. EPS from continuing operations was up 6% on the quarter. Importantly, when you consider the timing related to pension accounting, our FAS/CAS adjusted EPS of $1.27 was up 17%, driven by strong operational performance and capital deployment actions. And we generated solid operating cash flow from continuing operations of $257 million, which included Federal and foreign tax payments of $59 million.
Operating cash flow from continuing operations in the first quarter of 2009 was $411 million, which included a net tax refund of $323 million. Excluding these tax items, operating cash flow from continuing operations in the first quarter 2010 increased by $228 million, driven by business performance, our working capital focus, as well as timing. The company repurchased 5.5 million shares of common stock for $300 million in the quarter. And as we announced last month, the company's Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to an additional $2 billion of the company's outstanding common stock. At the end of the first quarter, a total of $2.6 billion remained available under the company's share repurchase programs.
In addition, the Board increased the company's annual dividend rate by 21%. We've now increased our dividend for six consecutive years. For the balance of 2010, we expect continued solid sales growth and strong operational performance. And we're reaffirming the positive guidance that we've provided in January. I'll discuss our guidance further in just a few minutes.
Turning now to Page 4, let me start by providing some detail on our first quarter results. Our total company booking for the quarter was $6.5 billion, resulting in a book-to-bill ratio greater than 1, a key indicator of our future growth outlook. Bill already mentioned a couple of our larger bookings during the quarter, including GPS-OCX, Zumwalt, the major classified awards at IIS and Missile Systems and ACES [Advanced Countermeasures Electronic System] at our SAS business. In addition, IDS booked $162 million to provide engineering services support for a Patriot air and missile defense program for U.S. and international customers.
MS booked $212 million for the development of SM-3 and $111 million for development work on the EKV program for the Missile Defense Agency. MS also booked $207 million for the production of SM-2 for an international customer and the U.S. Navy, $203 million for the production of Tomahawk cruise missiles for the U.S. Navy, $102 million for the production of the JSOW for the U.S. Navy and $95 million for production of TOW missiles for international customers in the U.S. Army. Our NCS business booked $138 million to supply Long Range Advanced Scout Surveillance systems for the U.S. Army. And TS booked $155 million on domestic training programs and $25 million on foreign training programs in support of the Warfighter FOCUS [Field Operations Customer Support] activities.
TS also booked $88 million on the Security Equipment Integration Services contract for the TSA and $78 million to provide operational and logistic support to the National Science Foundation Office of Polar Programs. Backlog at the end of the first quarter was $37 billion compared to $36.9 billion at the end of 2009.
If you’d now move to Page 5, we continue to deliver good sales growth. You should note that the first quarter of 2010 had one less work day than the same period last year. Normalized for the one day, I'd estimate our 3% sales growth in Q1 to be closer to the 5% range. Looking at sales by business, IDS had first quarter 2010 net sales of $1.3 billion, up 6% for the quarter, primarily due to growth on international Patriot programs.
IIS had first quarter 2010 net sales of $730 million. As we expected, the change in IIS sales was driven by volume on both the classified program and an international advanced border and security program. Missile Systems and NCS net sales were in line with the same period last year. Space and Airborne Systems had net sales of $1.1 billion in the quarter, up 5%, driven primarily by growth in classified business.
Technical services had first quarter 2010 net sales of $801 million, up 15%, driven by strength in domestic and foreign training programs supporting the U.S. Army. Our diverse portfolio of businesses all focused on customers’ priority areas is clearly driving our continued steady growth profile. 
Moving ahead to Page 6, we delivered strong operational performance in the quarter. Our margin before the FAS/CAS pension adjustment was up 70 basis points. Looking at business margins, IDS had solid results in the quarter. The increase in margin was primarily due to higher volume on international Patriot programs. At IIS, the change in margins was primarily due to an international program. Both MS and NCS margin in the quarter were in line with the same period in 2009. 
SAS margin in the quarter was up 120 basis points, primarily due to improved program performance and the change in contract mix. And finally, TS margin in the quarter was up 210 basis points, primarily due to improved performance mainly on programs nearing completion, as well as the timing and recognition of award fees on the fixed price service contract. Overall, total company margins continue to be strong.
Turning now to Page 7, first quarter EPS from continuing operations, which includes the FAS/CAS pension adjustment, was $1.18 versus $1.11 in 2009. The increase in EPS was primarily driven by operational improvement and reduced share count, partially offset by higher FAS/CAS pension expense.
2010 FAS/CAS adjusted EPS was $1.27, up 17%. If you’d move to Page 8, we are reaffirming the financial outlook for 2010 that we provided in January. We expect continued growth in sales in the range of between $25.9 billion and $26.4 billion, up 4% to 6%. And FAS/CAS adjusted EPS to be in the range of $5.13 to $5.28 per share, representing growth of between 6% and 9%. You should note that our outlook now reflects the impact of some warrants being exercised earlier than we had anticipated. More specifically, we've had about $6.5 million warrants exercised to date. The expiration of these warrants was June 2011. The full year 2010 EPS impact is approximately $0.05, which we expect to offset through improved performance.
Moving on to Page 9, we’ve provided additional color on our outlook for the year by business. The key takeaway’s that our strong and diverse portfolio is driving continued sales growth and solid margins. 
On Page 10, we provided some directional guidance on how we currently see sales, EPS, operating cash flow from continuing operations by quarter. We saw a good performance in the first quarter compared to both Q1 2009 and also the initial outlook for Q1 2010 that we provided in January. Some of this improvement was driven by timing.
So let me summarize our first quarter performance. We delivered another strong quarter with solid bookings, sales, EPS and cash flow. Our balance sheet remains very strong, and we are confident as we look ahead. Our shareholder focus was again highlighted by increasing the dividend by 21%, repurchasing 300 million shares of common stock and adding an additional $2 billion of share repurchase availability going forward.
We expect our strong results, both from a program performance and a financial perspective to continue to drive value for our customers and our shareholders. We're off to an excellent start for 2010. So with that, Bill and I will open up the call for questions.

Well, since I started down the SAS path, SAS was impacted by some customer requirements relative to deliveries in Q1 from an international program. Those we had expected later in the year, and those did favorably impact Q1, but again, we expect it to moderate somewhat as we go through the balance of the year. Notwithstanding, that business continues to perform well overall. There were significant operational and performance improvements that were also pulled ahead into Q1 for SAS. 
Now with respect to Technical Services, they have continued to perform well over the past few years. The results in Q1 are further attribution to that. Q1 was significantly impacted by an award fee from a fixed price service program, which we booked in Q1. It was worth a little over $5 million. If you take that out, the margins were just under 8%, still very, very healthy. That business continues to benefit from focusing on cost efficiencies and volume improvements.

componenttext: Troy, it's Bill. My perspective, the philosophy here is to keep driving our results through our Six Sigma processes to find ways to lean things out, do things quicker. If you can speed up your deliveries or your programs you, in essence, reduce your costs and get your margins up higher. The other part is we continue to work on the left-hand side of the margin curve. We keep narrowing it. And as we continue to narrow it, it makes our margins go up. Clearly, for us, I think it's safe to say as long as you're performing and you negotiate the fee rates you do up at the beginning, our customers don’t have any problem paying for those fee rates as long as you're performing. And you know our philosophy on execution and making -- execution of the program. I should clarify that -- to get it done right so they’re recognized. So from our standpoint, we're continuing to push to expand the margins and have done that at least seven years in a row and intend to keep it going.

Working capital turns, taken as a whole, continue to be very strong. We talked about this in the fourth quarter call. We generated close to $800 million in working capital improvements over the last four years.  Let me go back just to mention one other thing on the CIP. componenttext: First question, Bill, you mentioned the importance of technology at Raytheon earlier. And when you look at the last, really the last four quarters, your R&D spending, it's been up about 20% over what it had been in prior periods. I'm wondering if there's a renewed effort there to do more internally on technology? And if so, what's the focus?

headline: Raytheon Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I wouldn't say there's renewed focus here. Clearly, when the company had debt many years ago, $13 billion, a number I'll never forget, we, clearly, were still doing R&D. I think from a company's point of view, given our balance sheet and our strength
componenttext:
Yes. I wouldn't say there's renewed focus here. Clearly, when the company had debt many years ago, $13 billion, a number I'll never forget, we, clearly, were still doing R&D. I think from a company's point of view, given our balance sheet and our strength, we have the ability to look at different things. Of course, for us, getting funding from our government customers, our international customers, is still the best way to do it when you do some research. So I'd probably say there's good attention in that. But as far as we're concerned, we still have our own R&D funding. We still have our own enterprise campaigns. And we're continuing to look for disruptive technologies. I mentioned the cosmos. I mean, if you're an RF engineer and realize you can put a system on a chip and you can start to reduce your radar costs and power consumption costs, then you start to realize you've got some real game changers. So we've got a number of things, and I could go all day talking about technology, and the engineers would love it, but you all wouldn't. 
But from my standpoint, there's some exciting things going around the company in all areas, whether it be sensors, our FX business, our command-and-control, or how we look at it, even mission support. We were using 3D analysis, virtual.  Put the Warfighter in the middle of a virtual reality situation where they can experience what it's like in Iraq or Afghanistan in real-time so that they've got a feel for it before they get over there. Those are some of the exciting things that we’re doing, and I could just go on and on about the technology. But no, no change in focus. Just probably more of us trying to highlight it because people are curious at times of where we're going and what we are trying to do. And that's why I just mentioned a few of them on the call.

componenttext: Yes, if we see good opportunities, one of the things we have here in the company, if our engineers have a game changer, I mean, we are doing something called Tempway [ph] for example.  It turns out California, Florida, Canada and other parts of the country have trouble with frost.  Well, it’s a huge market if we can pull off how we hit – you know, in California or we have an experimental 1-acre parcel of an orange grove where we can actually raise the temperature in a clean way, no smudge pots, no environmental; it’s green. So we're a company of 50,000 engineers that are very, very creative. So, yes, there is an attention, and if they’ve got a good idea and we can see the market for it, we'll fund it.

componenttext: Bill, you had some terrible news in terms of your leadership this quarter. And you made some changes and moved some people around. There were quite a number of appointments. I was just wondering if you could comment on that and sort of the decisions you made. And then since we don't really meet these people who run these businesses very often, maybe just from a bigger picture standpoint, bring us up to speed on how you are thinking about the leadership of each of the businesses?

headline: Raytheon Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you for bringing it up.  I was trying to figure out how to make a comment. John Jones was a dear friend, somebody I'd worked with for many years, and he is truly missed. He had all the core values of the company. Clearly, Raytheon is a company that
componenttext:
Thank you for bringing it up.  I was trying to figure out how to make a comment. John Jones was a dear friend, somebody I'd worked with for many years, and he is truly missed. He had all the core values of the company. Clearly, Raytheon is a company that works hard on succession planning. It's recognized. Fortune ranked us in the top 25 in the nation as far as the development of leaders. Clearly, for us, unfortunately for John, it happened on a Saturday night, notified first thing Sunday morning because there was a time change between California and here. Clearly, we had a team ready to go in place within a few days. And it could have been immediately, but it was out of respect. And we've got Rick Hughes, who has got a perfect background for SAS.  He’s a radar guru, technical individual, ran major programs in the Missile Defense Agency, and what I call our dinosaur radars, those are the big three-story jobbers that can see for a long way, just let me put it that way. So Rick has managed big programs, managed technology and will have a steady hand on the tiller. 
John Harris, who ran our contract supply chain, has ran operations for me. John has been a direct-report one way or another for about 15 years, a very capable individual, understands that part of the business, knows every contract in the company and a long-time Raytheon employee. So he'll do well with some real passion. 
And David Wilkins, who came out of NCS in contracts will come right in. And for us, it's same old, same old. We're off and running. There's a deep loss, while at the same time we are a company of 75,000 people and a lot of talent, and we can react quickly and keep going. Beneath them is another group of individuals that we continue to push to develop so that the company is ready for anything that's handed to it at any point in time. And as CEO, succession planning is the most important thing that I do, and we're serious about it here. Thank you for asking. It was really, really tough. John was a terrific individual, not forgotten. And Rick would be the first to tell you that his intent is to keep doing what John was doing out there, because SAS was on a good path. And by the way, Marc, if people want to meet our leadership, we find ways to make that happen. We're very proud of them and would love for people to get to know them because you see the kind of talent that's in this company real quick.

componenttext:
Yes. Clearly for us, you know, part of our strategic look ahead. I sometimes get asked, you know, what do I think about speed and agility are still very important for us to take advantage of our portfolio. I think we demonstrate that with the thousands of programs we have and the broad-based nature of them. But we're continuing to work our GAAP analysis. I talked about investing internally. But we also look at teaming, and the last part is acquisitions. And if we can find acquisitions that help us narrow the gap quicker and they make sense and they have a good return on investment, then we're going to do them. But they're niche. They're like what we've been doing, nothing out of the ordinary. And then internationally, looking ahead strategically is staying very close to our customers and providing them solutions that they need. 
The other thing I should mention that wasn't asked is that we're really thrilled to see Secretary Gates, on the President's new export control reform initiative. The plan relies on four key reforms. There is the single export control list, the single licensing agency, and the single enforcement coordination agency and then what I'll call a single IT system controlling these critical technologies. And the crown jewels are important. Clearly, those of us in the business and our international customers believe the U.S. has one of the most stringent export regimes in the road. But stringent doesn't mean that it's effective and efficient. And so we are really welcoming what the President and Secretary Gates is doing to revamp the system. I would have liked to have seen it all done at once but that's just me as an engineer. But their three-phased approach is a very constructive way of looking at that. And I think that will help our industry, and given that we sell in 80 countries around the world, we're looking forward to it helping us.
